questions.question_text:
As per company policy, all administrator level accounts need to have their password changed on a regular basis. The cloudadmin@vmc.local account password is changed by an administrator from the vSphere Client.
Another administrator is using the credentials in the VMware Cloud console and gets an ‘access denied’ error.
What could be the problem?

choices.C: The new password is NOT synchronized with the password that is displayed for the Default vCenter user account.
choices.A: The password change email confirmation has NOT been approved by the organization owner.
choices.D: The password should be changed by escalation of privileges.
choices.B: The password should only be changed through the VMware Cloud console.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When you change the password for your SDDC from the vSphere Client, the new password is not synchronized with the password that is displayed on the Default vCenter Credentials page. That page shows only the Default credentials. If you change the credentials, you are responsible for keeping track of the new password.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questions.question_text:
A cloud administrator would like the VMware Cloud on AWS cluster to automatically scale-out and scale-in based on resource demand.
Which two Elastic DRS policies can be configured to meet this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
So, the correct answers are:
B. Optimize for Best Performance policy
C. Optimize for Lowest Cost policy
Best answers are B & C as there is no E, it's simply called 'Rapid Scaling'

Elastic Distributed Resource Scheduler (DRS) in VMware Cloud on AWS allows clusters to automatically scale based on resource demands. Among the options provided, the following are the Elastic DRS policies designed to handle automatic scale-out and scale-in scenarios:

B. Optimize for Best Performance policy: This policy is designed to maintain higher spare capacity and is quicker to add hosts when demand increases, ensuring optimal performance.

C. Optimize for Lowest Cost policy: This policy is more conservative in adding new hosts and will attempt to run the cluster closer to its limits before scaling out, thus reducing costs.

The other options provided aren't standard Elastic DRS policies for VMware Cloud on AWS as of my last update in 2022.

So, the correct answers are:
B. Optimize for Best Performance policy
C. Optimize for Lowest Cost policy
Could be B, C and E. All support scale out and scale in.

Selected Answer: BC
B&C are correct
